content:
I improved your statement and input in order to comply with the formating "rules". It's also simpler.
If it's ok for you, you can delete the previous and now obsolete part "Where
a is the starting number
n is how many bits will need flipped
Followed by a list of the bits to flip, one per line.
(x = 0 indicates the least significant bit)

a n
x (n times, one per line)"
Then I would accept the puzzle.

Your solution assumes binary operations - so you can flip bits  on larger positions than given number indicates.   
Not everyone should be forced to do this that way, so you have to explicitly say how many bits should be used to represent the number.

How is the bits numbered ? 

In your code it seems that 0 is the LSB, but you say that 0<xi, so we can understand that bit number starts at 1.

 Refusing until fixed.
Input and output sections should contain useful descriptions, not be just blank.

Under "Constraints" it is stated  < 16, so you will never be asked to work on anything larger than 16 bits.  None of the tests or validators violate those constraints.

The "Solution" doesn't check that the input is within bounds -- since the tests and validators are fixed it doesn't really need to.

As a note, you can solve this other ways than with binary operations.
(Edit: but binary operations are the easiest way!)

a = a + (pow(2,x)) would set a bit at x, for example.
I agree, this looks much better. Removed the old.

It is stated n<16, yes - but it does not  say we should always assume 16-bits.
(i.e. if I'm making list of bits by dividing, I got e.g. list of size 4; and tests are telling me to flip 10-th bit.
As the statement does not give a clue what is wrong, it makes hard to spot the error.
If you somehow make it  clear, I'll accept the puzzle.

I don't think I'm following what you are describing. I think that stating somewhere that a is an "Unsigned 16 bit integer" would make it less clear. Maybe I'm missing your point?

I chose to make the constraint 16 bits specifically so that the exact type isn't important to programming a solution. if you are going to make some list or array to handle [[a]], you should look to the constraints to see what size the list or array needs to be - a common enough part of any programming work.

You could use an unsigned short, a signed or unsigned int, or a signed or unsigned long long - all would yield correct answers.

Still, you enumerate form one not from zero x1..x2. 
So "x1 indicates the least significant bit"
I changed the way of indicating that.
